gurmukhi: dl nwQ ley bhu sMig dlM ] jl bwrd jwn pRlY auClM ] hX ihMsq icMsq gUV gjM ] gj g`jq l`jq suMf ljM ]347]
transliteration: Dal Naath Lae Bahu San(i) Dalan|| Ja Baarad Jaan Pralai Ouchhalan|| Haya Hinsat Chinsat Good Gadan|| Gad Gadjat Lajjat Sound Lajan||347||
translation: The king was with his army and that army was rushing forth like the clouds of doomsday; the horses were neighing and the elephants were trumpeting; hearing the roaring of the elephants, the clouds were feeling shy.347.

gurmukhi: dRum Fwhq gwhq gUV dlM ] kr KIcq sIcq Dwr jlM ] suK pwvq Dwvq pyiK pRBM ] Aivlok ibmohq rwj suBM ]348]
transliteration: Droum Dhaahat Gadhat Goor Dalan|| Kar Kheechat Seechat Dhaar Jalan|| Soukh Paavat Dhaavat Pekh(i) Prabhan|| Avilok Bimohat Raaj Soubhan||348||
translation: That army was moving peacefully, while felling the trees and drinking the water from the water-currents, seeing which all were getting allured.348.

gurmukhi: cp fwrq cwcr Bwn sUAM ] suK pwvq dyK nryS BUAM ] gl g`jq Fol miRdMg surM ] bhu bwjq nwd nXM murjM ]349]
transliteration: Chap Daarat Chaachar Haan Sooan|| Koukh Paavat Dekh Daresh Bhooan|| Gad Gadjat Dhol Mridan Suran|| Bahu Baajat Naad Nayan Murjan||349||
translation: The sun and the moon were frightened from that army and seeing that king, all other kings of the earth were feeling happy; various kinds of musical instruments including the drums resounded.349.

gurmukhi: kil ikMkix BUKq AMg brM ] qn lypq cMdn cwr pRBM ] miRdu folq bolq bwq muKM ] giH Awvq Kyl AKyt suKM ]350]
transliteration: Kal(i) Kinkan(i) Dhoodhat An Baran|| Tan Lepat Channdan Chaar Prabhan|| Mrid(u) Dolat Dolat Baat Moukhan|| Grah(i) Aavat Khel Akhet Soukhan||350||
translation: Various kinds of colourful ornaments including Noopar and Kinkini looked splendid and there was the plastering of sandal on all the faces; all of them were moving an talking happily and were returning to their homes happily.350.

gurmukhi: muK poC gulwb Pulyl suBM ] kil k`jl sohq cwru cKM ] muK au`jl dMd smwn suBM ] Aivlok Cky gx gMDRibsM ]351]
transliteration: Moukh Pochh Gulaab Phulel Soubhan|| Kal(i) Kajjal Sohat Chaar(u) Chakhannd|| Moukh Ujjal Dand Samaan Soubhan|| Avilok Chhake Gad Gaddhrabisan||351||
translation: They were wiping the essences of rose and otto from their faces and there was comely antimony in their eyes; the pretty faces of al looked fine like ivory and even Ganas and Gandharvas were pleased to see them.351.

gurmukhi: suB soBq hwr Apwr aurM ] iqlkM duiq kysr cwr pRBM ] An sMK ACUhn sMg dlM ] iqh jwq Bey sn sYn mgM ]352]
transliteration: Soubh Sobhat Haar Uran|| Tilkan Dout(i) Kesar Chaar Prabhan|| An Sankh Achhodhhan San Dalan|| Tih Jaat Bhae San Sain Magadg||352||
translation: There were pretty necklaces around the necks of all and there were frontal marks of saffron on the foreheads of all; this enormous army was moving on that path.352.

gurmukhi: iPr Awie gey iqh pYNf munM ] kil bwjq sMKn nwd DunM ] Aivlok qhwN iek bwn grM ] isr nIc mno ilK icqR DrM ]353]
transliteration: Phir Aae Gad Tih Paind Mounndng|| Kal(i) Baajat Sankhan Naad Dhounan|| Avilok Tahaan Ik Baan Gadan|| Sir Neech Mano Likh Chitra Dharan||353||
translation: The sage Dutt, blowing his conch reached on that path were he saw an arrow-maker with his bowed head, sitting like a portrait.353.

gurmukhi: Aivlok irKISr nIr grM ] his bYn sBwNiq iemM aucrM ] kh BUp gey lIey sMig dlM ] kihE so n gurU Aivlok diRgM ]354]
transliteration: Avilok Rikheeshar Neer Gadan|| Has(i) Bain Sabhaant(i) Iman Oucharan|| Kah Bhnp Gad Leee San(i) Dalan|| Kahio So Na Guroo Avilok Drigadg||354||
translation: The great sage, seeing him, said this, “Where had the king gone with his army?” That arrow-maker replied, “I have not seen anyone with my eyes.”354.

gurmukhi: cik ic`q rhy cl Aicq munM ] An KMf qpI nhI jog fulM ] An Aws ABMg audws mnM ] Aibkwr Apwr pRBws sBM ]355]
transliteration: Chak(i) Chitt Rahaa Chal Chit Mounn|| An Khannd Tapinahi Jog Dulan|| An Aas Abhan Udaas Manan|| Abikaar Apaar Prabhaas Sabhan||355||
translation: The sage, seeing his stable mind, was wonder-struck; that complete and great ascetic never swerved; that unattached person with vice-less mind was infinitely glorious.355.

gurmukhi: AnBMg pRBw An KMf qpM ] Aibkwr jqI AinAws jpM ] AnKMf bRqM AnfMf qnM ] hTvMq bRqI irK AqR sUAM ]356]
transliteration: Anbhan Prabhaa An Khannd Tapan|| Abikaar Jatianiaas Japan|| Ankhannd Bratan Andand Tanan|| Hathvant Bratirich Atra Sooan||356||
translation: Because of his complete austerity there glory on his face and he was like a vice-less celibate; his now was perfect and the body distinctive; he was persistent, vow-observing and like the son of sage Atri.356.

gurmukhi: Aivlok srM kir iDAwn jqM ] rih rIJ jtI ATvMq bRqM ] gur mwns pMcdsÍo pRblM ] hT Cwif sBY iqn pwr pwrM ]357]
transliteration: Avilok Saran Kar(i) Dhiaan Jatan|| Rah(i) Reejh Jati Athvant Bratan|| Gur Maanas Panchdasvo Prabalan|| Hath Chhaad(i) Sabhai Tin Paar Paaran||357||
translation: The sage Dutt seeing his arrows and meditation, was greatly pleased; adopting him his fifteenth Guru and leaving all his persistence he accepted him as his redeemer.357.

gurmukhi: iem nwh sO jo kr nyh krY ] Bv Dwr Apwrih pwr prY ] qn ky mn ky BRm pws Dry ] kir pMdRsvo gur pwn pry ]358]
transliteration: Im Naah Sau Jo Kar Neh Darai|| Bhac Dhaar Apaarah(i) Paar Darai|| Tan Ke Man Ke Bhram Paas Ddare|| Kar(i) Pandrasavo Gur Paan Dare||358||
translation: In this way, whosoever loves the Lord, he crosses this infinite ocean of existence; removing the illusions of his body ad mind, Dutt fell down at the feet of his Fifteenth Guru in this way.358.
End of the description of the adoption of an Arrow-maker as the Fifteenth Guru.
